utterances: Unbelievable.
Yeah, I think it's maybe they're just not used to it.
(Soundbite of laughter)
I mean, that's what I tell myself.
(Singing in French)
As the solo from ""Carmen"" ends, the other members of the Opera on Tap Company are sitting on the floor of the bar, drinking.
At just the right time, they, and even some of the amateurs in the audience, join in on the chorus.
(Singing in French)
The great thing about listening to opera and drinking all night is that everything takes on this epic quality - the struggle of young singers to get noticed in a cruel world.
(Singing in French)
…who the second one is.
So…
…is slated for demolition under a plan to build a new basketball arena on the site.
Operas don't always have happy endings, but as long as there is beer and a stage somewhere, the company says they'll find another place to sing along.
(Singing in foreign language)
(Soundbite of cheering and applause)
Robert Smith, NPR News, New York.
And to hear some of the full opera performances from Freddy's bar and watch the Opera on Tap Company in action, go to our Web site, npr.org.
(Soundbite of music)
That's ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
I'm Jacki Lyden.
Debbie Elliott will be back next week.
According to government figures, nearly 600 veterans of Iraq and Afghanistan were homeless last year.
Well, count Corporal Joe Raicaldo among this year's numbers.
On December 10, 2004, Raicaldo was on combat patrol near Baghdad with his National Guard unit.
His Humvee took a sharp turn and flipped.
Raicaldo was in the gunner's turret.
For months, Army doctors worked to put him back together and then they sent him home to Long Island.
He came back with a few things he didn't take with him - an honorable discharge, metal rods and screws up and down his spine, an arm that moves like a robot's and a bone infection.
The first place Raicaldo went was the New York Armory to pick up his '98 Plymouth.
He's been living in it pretty much ever since.
NPR's Libby Lewis spent a day with him.
There are days when Joe Raicaldo goes all day without talking to anybody.
He's like a ghost in his hometown.
His parents and aunts and uncles have passed on.
He has one sister and a few friends here in Nassau County.
They wish he would call, but he doesn't much.
I try to keep to myself, you know?
Is that the way you are naturally or is it because of -
No.
You know, the first thing people want to do is want to help and I appreciate it, this and that, but you know, I feel like I just don't want to burden anyone.
What he wants is to go back to work.
He tried at first.
He couldn't go back to being a car mechanic with that arm, so he went to work at New York's Penn Station as one of the National Guardsmen who've patrolled the place since 9/11.
He couldn't afford to live in the city.
He decided to sleep in his car.
The social worker at the Veterans Affairs Medical Center told him he could stay at the Salvation Army shelter for veterans.
The way I feel is like, you know, I'm going to be 50 and I never had to live anywhere other than where I wanted to live.
I've worked my whole life and I just told them straight out, keep your shelter for the cats and dogs because I'll do something before I, you know.
Anyway, here's the (unintelligible) I used to go to.
I grew up in this town.
It's no big deal, but that's mom and dad, Sunday there.
That's still there, thank God.
He lasted six months at Penn Station.
He said the pain in his back and his infections got to be too much.
NPR spoke with officials with the National Guard and the VA about Raicaldo and obtained some of Raicaldo's medical records.
VA records show he's been rated 20 percent disabled on a scale of 1 to 100, so he's been living on $218 a month in disability from the VA, some savings and his Plymouth.
He's appealed his case but that usually takes a long time.
Raicaldo drives across town to show me where he grew up in Hicksville.
The siding on his old house looks new.
He doesn't know the people who live here now.
They gave me an American flag at the Pentagon.
I've seen Rumsfeld twice.
I met with him, and I was thinking about coming here one night and just burying it on this property, you know, so these people would never know.
I guess part of me just wants to have something to do still.
The only ties I've ever known in my life is this property.
There may be a part of me that just wants to bury that flag because I just don't want to look at it anymore.
He wound up giving the flag to his oldest friend, Beau Silverman.
They met when they were eight.
We used to meet at this corner here.
Raicaldo wants me to see his friend's house from the street.
There's a white Mercedes in the driveway.
Silverman built up a business at the local flea market.
He loaned Raicaldo money to start his own business, but it didn't work out.
So for the longest time I stayed away because I couldn't pay him back.
One thing led to another and I ended up getting into, you know, financial situations but he's a true American.
He had nothing and he built a business up, and that's what the American dream is.
You know, guys like me, you know, we just like ruin the American dream, you know?
We just don't live up fully to what it should be.
You know, he's one person I've known my whole life, so I presented him the flag.
I went to his booth in the flea market.
I just gave it to him and that was like the best thing I probably remember.
He has a sister.
She wants to help.
So do his friends.
But Raicaldo wants to do it by himself.
We get gas.
Seven dollars.
He paid.
People are very impatient.
Yeah.
It's amazing when you have nowhere to go, how much time you have, you just don't care about getting anywhere.
The worst feeling for me is being useless.
That's just what I am.
I'm just like, just annoying people.
Taking up space.
That's why I pushed everybody out.
He keeps the Plymouth neat.
He eats once a day, mostly Chinese.
Around 5:00 p.m., when things get busy, he sneaks into the gym he used to belong to and showers.
We decide to get coffee.
Everything in front of us is strip malls.
Well, that's my laundromat.
It's 24 hours.
That's where I sleep.
Where that truck is?
Other times it's a church parking lot down there.
That's the safest one.
At the stop light he pulls out a stack of pictures from Iraq.
There's a blood orange sunset.
One of Raicaldo and his buddies.
There's one picture of a boy.
He looks 10 or 11.
His whole family got killed in a bombing raid.
(Soundbite of laughter)

I would say to him that we should have a stimulus in the area that they're talking about, which is somewhere - they're talking about $140 billion, I believe, and it worth hundreds to hundred forty billion.
I believe a good part of it should be tax rebates that are focused predominantly on lower and middle-income people.
I think it should include those - the full rebates should go to the 50 million low-income workers who pay payroll taxes.
But in some case who don't pay any income taxes.
In other case, pay very small income taxes.

And I think you probably also should have some measures in there that would also have very immediate effect such as extending the unemployment insurance time, additional food stamps, measures of that kind, Michele, that will have an effect on the economy, on demand of the economy right away.

A difficult question to ask you in particular, but do you feel any personal responsibility for what we're seeing right now because of Citigroup's involvement in the mortgage market, or because of Wall Street's involvement or posture overall?
No, Michele.
Look, I'm sorry I wasn't involved in this activity at Citigroup.
But this is really sort of a current manifestation, if you will, of what has been the whole history of financial markets, which is one of excess leading disruption.

And then, it seems to me the key once these things happen is to focus quickly both within each institution and also systemically in terms of our overall economic system and try to address the immediate problems.
I asked the question not necessarily because your hands were on the levers…
Yes.
…but you're seen as one of the wisest of the wise men on Wall Street.
And I wonder if you ever - wished that you had perhaps spoken up or raise this issue?
